ODS MARKUP|HTML|CHTML|HTMLCSS|HTML3|IMODE|PHTML|CSVALL|DOCBOOK|WML|SASREPORT|TROFF|
  HTML4|LATEX|WMLOLIST<(<ID=>identifier)> <option(s)><TAGSET=tagset-name> <action>;

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: EXCLUDE exclusion(s)| ALL | NONE 
          
Excludes one or more output objects from the destination.
Closes the destination and any files that are associated with it.
See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.
See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.

Syntax: SELECT selection(s) | ALL | NONE 
          
Selects one or more output objects for the specified destination.
Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

[Syntax: ANCHOR='anchor-name'] 
          
Specifies a unique base name for the anchor tag that identifies each output object 
in the current body file.

[Syntax: ARCHIVE='string'] 
          
The ARCHIVE= option is only valid for the GOPTIONS Java device. The ARCHIVE= option 
allows you to specify a string to identify which applet to use in order to view the 
ODS HTML output.

[Syntax: ATTRIBUTES=(attribute-pair-1 ... attribute-pair-n)] 
          
Writes the specified attributes between the tags that generate dynamic graphics output.

[Syntax: BASE= 'base-text'] 
          
Specifies the text to use as the first part of all links and references that ODS 
creates in the output files.

[Syntax: BODY= 'file-specification' <sub-option(s)>] 
          
Opens a MARKUP family destination and specifies the file that contains the primary 
output that is created by the ODS statement.

[Syntax: CHARSET=character-set] 
          
Specifies the character set to be generated in the META declaration for the HTML output.

[Syntax: CODE= 'file-specification' <sub-option(s)>] 
          
Opens a MARKUP family destination and specifies the file that contains relevant 
style information, such as XSL (Extensible Stylesheet Language).

[Syntax: CODEBASE='string'] 
          
Creates a file path that is used by the GOPTIONS devices.

Syntax: CONTENTS= 'file-specification' <(suboption(s))> 
          
Opens a markup family destination and specifies the file that contains a table of contents for 
the output. These files remain open until you do one of the following:

  o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement or 
    ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement.

  o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first file 
    and opens the second file.

file-specification -- specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. 

  file-specification is one of the following:

  external-file --  is the name of an external file to write to.
  Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

  fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to 
  assign a fileref. 

  entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to. 

suboption(s) -- specifies one or more suboptions in parentheses. Suboptions are instructions for 
writing the output files.

Specifies the name of a device driver. ODS automatically selects an optimal default device for each 
open output destination.

[Syntax: ENCODING=local-character-set-encoding] 
          
Overrides the encoding for input or output processing (transcodes) of external files.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Arabic
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Baltic
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Central Europe
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Cyrillic
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Greek

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: EVENT=event-name (FILE= | FINISH | LABEL= | NAME= | START | STYLE= |TARGET= | TEXT= | URL= )
    
Specifies an event and the value for event variables that are associated with the event.

Syntax: FRAME='file-specification' <sub-option(s)> 
    
Opens a MARKUP family destination and, for HTML output, specifies the file that integrates the table 
of contents, the page contents, and the body file.

Prints footnotes that are created by SAS/GRAPH, the SGPLOT procedure, the SGPANEL procedure, or the 
SGSCATTER procedure. The footnotes appear inside the graph borders.  If you open the frame file, 
then you see a table of contents, a table of pages, or both, as well as the body file. For XLM 
output, FRAME= specifies the file that contains the DTD. These files remain open until you do 
one of the following:

  o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement.

  o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first file and opens the second file.

file-specification 
specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. file-specification is one of the following:

    external-file -- is the name of an external file to write to.
    Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

    fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. 

    entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to. 

suboption(s) 
specifies one or more suboptions in parentheses. Suboptions are instructions for writing the output files.
Prints footnotes that are created by ODS, which appears outside the graph borders.

Syntax: GPATH= 'aggregate-file-storage-specification' | fileref | libref.catalog (URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE)  
   
Specifies the location for all graphics output that is generated while the destination is open. 

  'aggregate-file-storage-location' 
  specifies an aggregate storage location such as directory, folder, or partitioned data set.
  Requirement: You must enclose aggregate-file-storage-location in quotation marks. 

  fileref 
  is a file reference that has been assigned to an aggregate storage location. Use the FILENAME 
  statement to assign a fileref.

  libref.catalog -- specifies a SAS catalog to write to.

  URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE --  specifies a URL for file-specification. 

    Uniform-Resource-Locator -- is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in 
    all the links and references that it creates to the file.
    Requirement: You must enclose Uniform-Resource-Locator in quotation marks. 

    NONE -- specifies that no information from the GPATH= option appears in the links or references.

Prints the title that is created by SAS/GRAPH, the SGPLOT procedure, the SGPANEL procedure, or the 
SGSCATTER procedure. The title appears inside the graph borders.
Prints the title that is created by ODS, which appears outside the graph borders.

Specifies tags to place between the <HEAD> and </HEAD> tags in all the files that the destination 
writes to. 

Syntax: HEADTEXT= 'markup-document-head' 

where:

  markup-document-head 
  specifies the markup tags to place between the <HEAD> and </HEAD> tags.

  Requirement: You must enclose markup-document-head in quotation marks.

[Syntax: (ID=identifier)] 
          
Enables you to run multiple instances of the same destination at the same time. 
Each instance can have different options.

Specifies the image resolution for graphical output. Default: 100. 
          
Restriction: The IMAGE_DPI= option affects template-based graphics only.

Specifies HTML code to use as the <META> tag between the <HEAD> and </HEAD> tags of all the HTML 
files that the destination writes to. 

Syntax: METATEXT= 'metatext-for-document-head' 

where:

  'metatext-for-document-head' 
  specifies the HTML code that provides the browser with information about the document that it is loading. 
  For example, this attribute could specify the content type and the character set to use.

  Requirement: You must enclose metatext-for-document-head in quotation marks.

[Syntax: NEWFILE=starting-point] 
          
Creates a new body file at the specified starting-point.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Starts a new file for the results of each BY group.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Writes all output to the body file that is currently open.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Starts a new body file for each output object.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Starts a new body file for each page of output.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Starts a new body file each time that you start a new procedure.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: OPTIONS ( DOC= | <suboption(s)> )] 
          
Specifies tagset-specific suboptions and a named value.

(DOC='QUICK' | 'HELP' | 'SETTINGS') 
provides information about the specified tagset. 

  QUICK 
  describes the options available for this tagset. 

  HELP 
  provides generic help and information with a quick reference.

  SETTINGS 
  provides the current option settings.

suboption(s) 
specifies one or more suboptions that are valid for the specified tagset. Suboptions have the 
following format: 

  keyword='value'  
  You can get information about suboptions for a specific tagset by specifying one of the following 
  options when opening an ODS tagset statement or at any time after the destination has been opened. 
    
    options(doc='help');
    options(doc='quick'); 
    options(doc='settings');

[Syntax: PACKAGE <package-name>] 
          
Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package.

Syntax: PAGE= 'file-specification' <(suboption(s))> 
          
Opens a markup family destination and specifies the file that contains a description 
of each page of the body file, and contains links to the body file. ODS produces a 
new page of output whenever a procedure requests a new page. These files remain open 
until you do one of the following:

  o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement 
    or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement.

  o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first 
    file and opens the second file.

file-specification 
specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. 

    file-specification is one of the following:

    external-file -- is the name of an external file to write to.
    Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

    fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME 
    statement to assign a fileref. 

    entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to. 
    Interaction: If you specify an entry name, you must also specify a library and catalog.  

suboption(s) 
specifies one or more suboptions in parentheses. Suboptions are instructions for writing the output files.

Syntax: PARAMETERS=(parameter-pair-1 ... parameter-pair-n) 
          
Writes the specified parameters between the tags that generate dynamic graphics output.

  parameter-pair 
  specifies the name and value of each parameter. parameter-pair has the following form: 

    'parameter-name'= 'parameter-value'  

  where:
  
  parameter-name -- is the name of the parameter.

  parameter-value -- is the value of the parameter.
  Requirement: You must enclose parameter-name and parameter-value in quotation marks.

Syntax: PATH= 'aggregate-file-storage-specification' | fileref | libref.catalog (URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE) 
   
Specifies the location of an aggregate storage location or a SAS catalog for all markup files. 
If the GPATH= option is not specified, all graphics output files are written to the 
"aggregate-file-storage-specification" or libref.

  'aggregate-file-storage-location' -- specifies an aggregate storage location such as directory, folder, or partitioned data set.
  Requirement: You must enclose aggregate-file-storage-location in quotation marks. 

  fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an aggregate storage location. 
  Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref.

    Interaction: If you use a fileref in the PATH= option, then ODS does not use information from 
    PATH= when it constructs links. 

  libref.catalog -- specifies a SAS catalog to write to.

  URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE -- specifies a URL for the file-specification. 

    Uniform-Resource-Locator 
    is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references that it creates to the file.

    NONE 
    specifies that no information from the PATH= option appears in the links or references.

Syntax: RECORD_SEPARATOR= 'alternative-separator' | NONE 
    
Specifies an alternative character or string that separates lines in the output files.

Different operating environments use different separator characters. If you do not specify a record 
separator, then the files are formatted for the environment where you run the SAS job. However, 
if you are generating files for viewing in a different operating environment that uses a different 
separator character, then you can specify a record separator that is appropriate for the target environment.

alternative-separator -- represents one or more characters in hexadecimal or ASCII format. For example, 
the following option specifies a record separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character 
for use with an ASCII file system: 

  RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D0A'x
  
Operating Environment Information:   In a mainframe environment, the option that specifies a record 
separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character for use with an ASCII file system is: 

  RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D25'x
  Requirement: You must enclose alternative-separator in quotation marks. 

NONE -- produces the markup language that is appropriate for the environment where you run the SAS job.

[Syntax: STYLE= style-definition] 
          
Specifies the style definition to use in writing the output files.

Syntax: STYLESHEET= 'file-specification' <sub-option(s)> 
    
Opens a markup family destination and places the style information for markup output into an external 
file, or reads style sheet information from an existing file. These files remain open until you do one 
of the following:

  o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement.

  o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first file and opens the second file.

file-specification -- specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. 

file-specification is one of the following:

    external-file 
    is the name of an external file to write to.
    Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

    fileref 
    is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. 

    entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to.
    Interaction: If you specify an entry name, you must also specify a library and catalog. See the discussion 
    of the PATH= option. 

suboption(s) -- specifies one or more suboptions in parentheses.

Specifies a keyword value for a tagset. A tagset is a template that defines how to 
create an output type from a SAS format.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Produces compact, minimal HTML output that does not use style information.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Contains a table of Unicode values and mnemonics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Produces tabular output that contains  columns of data values that are separated by commas.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Produces tabular output with titles that contain columns of data values that are separated by commas.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Produces output with comma-separated values and columns of data that are separated by commas.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Produces XML output that conforms to the DocBook DTD by OASIS.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Produces Microsoft's spreadsheetML XML. This tagset is used to import data into XML.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip10: produces HTML output with cascading style sheets that is similar to ODS HTML output.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip12: produces HTML output as a column of output that is separated by lines.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip13: Produces HTML code for output generated by ODS for Microsoft Office products.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip14: Produces URLs within HTML files that are used in the z/OS operating environment.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip15: Produces simple HTML output that uses twelve style elements and no class attributes.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip16: Produces PYX, which is a simple, line-oriented notation used by Pyxie to describe the information  communicated by an XML parser to an XML application.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip18: Causes imbedded data to be produced in CSV format.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip19: Uses the Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) to produce a Wireless Markup Language (WML) DTD with  a list of URLs as a table of contents.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip20: Uses the Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) to produce a Wireless Markup Language (WML) DTD with  an option list for the table of contents.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip22: Creates XML output that shows which events are being triggered and which variables are used by an  event to send output from a SAS process to an output file.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip23: Creates HTML output similar to STYLE_POPUP, but with all the objects labeled as they are when  using ODS TRACE.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip24: Creates a subset of the XML output that is created by the EVENT_MAP tagset.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip25: Creates a sample page of HTML output that is similar to STYLE_POPUP output.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip26: Creates HTML like HTMLCSS, but if you're using Internet Explorer, STYLE_POPUP displays a window  that shows the resolved ODS style definition for any item that you select.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip27: Creates text output that shows which events are being triggered as ODS handles the output objects.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip28: Creates HTML output in a bulleted list similar to EVENT_MAP but lists only a subset of the  possible attributes.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip29: Creates XML output similar to EVENT_MAP but lists only a subset of the possible attributes.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: TEXT='variable-value'] 
          
Inserts text into your document by triggering the paragraph event and specifying 
a text string to be assigned to the VALUE event variable.

Syntax: TRANTAB= 'translation-table' 
          
Specifies the translation table to use when transcoding a file for output.

Syntax: EXCLUDE exclusion(s)| ALL | NONE 
          
Excludes output objects from the destination.
Closes the destination and any files that are associated with it.
See the EXCLUDE or SELECT option.
See the EXCLUDE or SELECT option.

Syntax: SELECT selection(s) | ALL | NONE 
          
Selects output objects for the specified destination.
Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

[Syntax: ANCHOR='anchor-name'] 
          
Specifies the root name for the anchor tag that identifies each output object 
in the current file.

[Syntax: AUTHOR='author-text'] 
          
Inserts into the metadata of a file, the text string that you specify as the author.

Specifies the text to use as the first part of all references that ODS creates in the output files.

Syntax: BASE= 'base-text'

base-text 
is the text that ODS uses as the first part of all references that ODS creates in the file.

Consider this specification: 

BASE='http://www.your-company.com/local-url/'
In this case, ODS creates references that begin with the string http://www.your-company.com/local-url/. 
The appropriate anchor-name completes the link.
Specifies whether to generate and display the list of bookmarks for a PDF file.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Generates a list of bookmarks for your PDF file. The bookmarks are not automatically displayed when  you open the PDF file.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies not to generate a list of bookmarks for your PDF file.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Generates a list of bookmarks for your PDF file. The bookmarks are automatically displayed when you  open the PDF file.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Controls the generation of bookmarks in a PDF file.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies not to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.
Specifies not to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.
Applies the specified color scheme to your output.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Creates full color output for both text and graphics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Creates gray scale output for both text and graphics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Creates monochromatic output for both text and graphics.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Does not use all the color information that the style definition provides.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Uses all the color information that a style definition provides, including background color.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: COLUMNS=n] 
          
Specifies the number of columns to place across each page of output. 
            
n 
is the number columns per page.

Default: 1

[Syntax: COMPRESS=n] 
          
Controls the compression of a PDF file. Compression reduces the size of the file.
            
n 
specifies the level of compression. The larger the number, the greater the compression. 
For example, n=0 is completely uncompressed, and n=9 is the maximum compression level. 

Default: 6 
Range: 0-9
Controls the generation of a printable table of contents.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Does not generate a printable table of contents.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Generates a printable table of contents.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Generates a printable table of contents page.
Does not generate a printable table of contents.

Syntax: CSSSTYLE='file-specification'<(media-type-1 <...media-type-10>)> 
    
Specifies a cascading style sheet to apply to your output. 

file-specification 
specifies a file, fileref, or URL that contains CSS code. 

    file-specification is one of the following:

    "external-file" 
    is the name of the external file.
    Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

    fileref 
    is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. 

    "URL" 
    is a URL to an external file.
    Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

(media-type-1<.. media-type-10>) 
specifies one or more media blocks that corresponds to the type of media that your output will be 
rendered on. CSS uses media type blocks to specify how a document is to be presented on different 
media: on the screen, on paper, with a speech synthesizer, with a braille device, and so on.

Specifies the image resolution for output files. Default: 150 
          
Restriction: The DPI= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file.

Syntax: FILE='external-file' | fileref 
          
Specifies the file that contains the output. 

  external-file 
  is the name of an external file to write to.
  Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

  fileref 
  is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement 
  to assign a fileref.

Specifies that ODS use the printer drivers that the host system provides. 
          
Interaction: In an ODS printer family statement that refers to an open ODS PRINTER destination, 
the HOST option forces ODS to close the destination and all files that are associated with it, 
and to open a new instance of the destination.

[Syntax: KEYWORDS='keywords-text'] 
          
Inserts into the output file's metadata, a string of keywords. 
          
Restriction: Use this option only with the ODS PDF statement, the ODS PS statement with the 
PDFMARK option specified, and the ODS PRINTER statement with the PDFMARK option specified. 

Restriction: The KEYWORDS= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file. 

Requirement: You must enclose keywords-text in quotation marks.

[Syntax: (<ID=>identifier)] 
          
Enables you to open multiple instances of the same destination at the same time. Each 
instance can have different options.
Creates a new file at the specified starting-point.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Starts a new file for the results of each BY group.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Writes all output to the file that is currently open.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Starts a new file for each output object. For SAS/GRAPH this means that ODS creates a new file  for each SAS/GRAPH output file that the program generates.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Starts a new file for each page of output. A page break occurs when a procedure explicitly starts  a new page (not because the page size was exceeded) or when you start a new procedure.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Starts a body file each time that you start a new procedure.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that ODS omit the table of contents (Bookmark list) that is produced by default when 
producing PDF or PDFMARK output. 

Interaction: The NOTOC option specifies BOOKMARKLIST=OFF and CONTENTS= OFF.

[Syntax: PACKAGE <package-name>] 
          
Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package. 
          
package-name 
specifies the name of a package that was created with the ODS PACKAGE statement. If no name 
is specified, then the output is added to the unnamed package that was opened last.

Creates PCL output. 
         
Restriction: Do not use this option in conjunction with the PDF or PS option. 

Interaction: If you use the PCL option in an ODS PRINTER statement that refers to an open 
ODS PRINTER destination, the option will force ODS to close the destination and all files 
that are associated with it, and to open a new instance of the destination.

Creates PDF output. 
          
Restriction: Do not use this option in conjunction with the PCL or PS option. 

Interaction: If you use the PDF option in an ODS PRINTER statement that refers to an open 
ODS PRINTER destination, the option will force ODS to close the destination and all files 
that are associated with it, and to open a new instance of the destination.]

Enables ODS to insert special tags into a PostScript file. When you use software such as Adobe Acrobat 
(not Adobe Viewer), Acrobat Distiller interprets the tags to create a PDF file that contains the 
following items: 

  o bookmarks for each section of the output and for each table.

  o references for items that are associated with the URL= style attribute.

  o notes for items that are associated with the FLYOVER= style attribute. 
    Notes are optional, and are based on the PDFNOTE option.

  o author, keywords, subject, and title in the metadata of a file.
Adds notes to a PDF file for items that are associated with the FLYOVER= style attribute.

Modifies the behavior of PDFMARK so that notes are not added to the file for items that are associated 
with the FLYOVER= style attribute.

[Syntax: PDFTOC=n] 
          
Controls the level of the expansion of the table of contents in PDF documents.

[Syntax: PRINTER=printer-name] 
          
Creates output that is formatted for the specified printer. 
          
Default: If you do not specify a printer, then ODS formats the printer output for the printer 
that is specified by one of two SAS system options: 
  
  o SYSPRINT= if you are using the Windows operating environment and do not specify any of the
    following options: PCL, PDFMARK, POSTSCRIPT, PS, or SAS.

  o PRINTERPATH= in all other cases.
 
Restriction: printer-name must match a subkey in either the SAS registry or the Windows 
printer registry.
Creates PostScript output.
Controls page breaks.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies not to insert page breaks, even before graphics procedures.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that no new pages be inserted at the beginning of each procedure, or within certain  procedures, even if new pages are requested by the procedure code. A new page will begin only  when a page is filled or when you specify STARTPAGE=NOW.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Forces the immediate insertion of a new page.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Inserts a new page at the beginning of each procedure, and within certain procedures, as requested  by the procedure code.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: STYLE=style-definition] 
          
Specifies the style definition to use in writing the printer output.

[Syntax: SUBJECT='subject-text'] 
          
Inserts into the metadata of a file the text string that you specify as the subject.

subject-text 
is the text in the metadata of a file that indicates the subject.

Restriction: Use this option only with the ODS PDF statement, the ODS PS statement with the 
PDFMARK option specified, and the ODS PRINTER statement with the PDFMARK option specified. 

Restriction: The SUBJECT= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file. 

Requirement: You must enclose subject-text in quotation marks.

[Syntax: TEXT='text-string'] 
          
Inserts a text string into your output. 
          
Requirement: You must enclose text-string in quotation marks.

[Syntax: TITLE='title-text'] 
          
Inserts into the metadata of a file, the text string that you specify as the title. 

Restriction: Use this option only with the ODS PDF statement, the ODS PS statement with the 
PDFMARK option specified, and the ODS PRINTER statement with the PDFMARK option specified. 

Restriction: The TITLE= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file. 

Requirement: You must enclose title-text in quotation marks.

For multiple page tables, ensures uniformity from page to page within a single table. 
When the UNIFORM option is in effect, ODS reads the entire table before it starts to 
print it so that it can determine the column widths that are necessary to accommodate 
all the data. These column widths are applied to all pages of a multiple page table. 

Note: With BY-group processing, SAS writes the results of each BY group to a separate 
table, so the output might not be uniform across BY groups.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ODS PROCTITLE; 
      
Writes, in the output, the name of the procedure that produces the results.

Syntax: ODS NOPROCTITLE;
      
Suppresses the writing of the title of the procedure that produces the results.

Enables you to change a procedure label.
      
Syntax: ODS PROCLABEL 'string';
      
where:

'string' is the procedure label that you specify.

Syntax: ODS RESULTS ON | OFF; 
      
Tracks ODS output in the Results window.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Tracks output that ODS generates in the Results window.
Turns off the tracking of output that ODS generates in the Results window.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Inserts text into your ODS output. 
      
Syntax: ODS TEXT= 'text-string';
      
where:

text-string
specifies the text to insert into your output. This text is sent to all open supported 
output destinations.

Restriction:  The ODS TEXT= statement does not support the OUTPUT destination or the LISTING 
destination. All other ODS destinations are supported. 

Requirement:  You must enclose 'text-string' in parentheses. 

Tip:  The UserText style element controls text specified with the TEXT= statement.
Syntax: ODS TRACE ON </option(s)>; |  ODS TRACE OFF;

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Turns on the writing of the trace record.
Turns off the writing of the trace record.
Includes, in the trace record, information for excluded output objects.

Includes the label path for the output object in the record. You can use a label path anywhere that 
you can use a path.

Writes the trace record to the Listing destination, so that each part of the trace record immediately 
precedes the output object that it describes.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ODS USEGOPT; 
      
Specifies that ODS use traditional SAS/GRAPH option settings for non-graphical output.

Syntax: ODS NOUSEGOPT; 
      
Specifies that ODS not use traditional SAS/GRAPH option settings for non-graphical output.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Prints the warning and sends output objects to open destinations.
Suppresses the warning.

Prints an error message instead of a warning message and does not send output objects 
to open destinations.
Prints a warning message and does not send output objects to open destinations.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Defines a representative character to be used in output strings.
      
Syntax: ODS ESCAPECHAR= 'escape-character';

escape-character 
specifies the special character that identifies the inline formatting symbol. The 
escape-character should be one of the following rarely used characters: @, ^, or \.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: EXCLUDE exclusion(s)| ALL | NONE 
          
Excludes output objects from the RTF destination.
Closes the RTF destination and any files that are associated with it.
See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.
See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.

Syntax: SELECT selection(s) | ALL | NONE 
          
Selects output objects for the RTF destination.
Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

[Syntax: ANCHOR='anchor-name'] 
          
Specifies the base name for the RTF anchor tag that identifies each output object 
in the current file.

[Syntax: AUTHOR='author-text'] 
          
Inserts the text string that you specify as the author into the metadata of a file.

Specifies the text to use as the first part of all references that ODS creates in the output files.

Syntax: BASE= 'base-text'

base-text 
is the text that ODS uses as the first part of all references that ODS creates in the file.

Consider this specification: 

BASE='http://www.your-company.com/local-url/'
In this case, ODS creates references that begin with the string http://www.your-company.com/local-url/. 
The appropriate anchor-name completes the link.

Specifies that SAS titles and footnotes are placed into the body of the RTF document 
instead of into the headers and footers section of the RTF document.

Restriction: The BODYTITLE option can be specified only when you create a new RTF file.

Specifies that SAS titles and footnotes be placed into the body of the RTF document 
instead of into the headers and footers section of the RTF document. These titles 
and footnotes are put into cells, which allows titles and footnotes to be centered, 
left-justified, or right-justified.

Restriction: You can specify the BODYTITLE_AUX option only when you are creating a 
new RTF file.

[Syntax: COLUMNS=n | MAX] 
          
Specifies the number of columns to place across each page of output. 
            
Default: the number of one-inch columns that fit on the page.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Is the number of one-inch columns that you want on the page.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the maximum number of one-inch-wide columns for the paper size and margin setting.  This value is dependent upon the paper size and page orientation.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Produces a table of contents page for RTF documents that are opened in Microsoft Word. 
The table of contents page contains a Table of Contents field, which puts all of the 
contents information that is embedded in the document into a table of contents. To 
expand the table of contents, right-click under the title in Microsoft Word and select 
Update Field from the selection list. 

Restriction: Do not use the CONTENTS option with the NEWFILE option.

Syntax: CSSSTYLE='file-specification'<(media-type-1 <...media-type-10>)> 
    
Specifies a cascading style sheet to apply to your output. 

file-specification 
specifies a file, fileref, or URL that contains CSS code. 

    file-specification is one of the following:

    "external-file" 
    is the name of the external file.
    Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

    fileref 
    is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME 
    statement to assign a fileref. 

    "URL" 
    is a URL to an external file.
    Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. 

(media-type-1<.. media-type-10>) 
specifies one or more media blocks that corresponds to the type of media that your 
output will be rendered on. CSS uses media type blocks to specify how a document is 
to be presented on different media: on the screen, on paper, with a speech synthesizer, 
with a braille device, and so on.

Specifies the name of a device driver. ODS automatically selects an optimal default 
device for each open output destination.

[Syntax: ENCODING=local-character-set-encoding] 
          
Overrides the encoding for input or output processing (transcodes) of external files.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Arabic
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Baltic
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Central Europe
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Cyrillic
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Greek

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Opens the RTF destination and specifies the RTF file or SAS catalog to which to write. This file 
remains open until you do one of the following actions:

  o Close the RTF destination with ODS RTF CLOSE or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE.

  o Specify a different file to which to write.

Syntax: FILE= 'external-file' | fileref

  'external-file' 
  is the name of an external file to which to write.

  fileref 
  is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file.
Includes all of the currently defined footnotes within the graphics output.

Prevents all of the currently defined footnotes from appearing in the graphics file. Instead, 
they become part of the RTF file.

Includes all of the currently defined titles within the graphics output that is called 
by the body file.

Prevents all of the currently defined titles from appearing in the graphics output. 
Instead, the titles become part of the RTF file.

[Syntax: (ID=identifier)] 
          
Enables you to run multiple instances of the same destination at the same time. 
Each instance can have different options.

Specifies the image resolution for graphical output. Default: 200. 
          
Restriction: The IMAGE_DPI= option affects template-based graphics only.
ODS allows table splits only if the entire table cannot fit on one page.
ODS lets a table split at a page break.

[Syntax: NEWFILE=starting-point] 
          
Creates a new file at the specified starting-point.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Starts a new file for the results of each BY group.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Writes all output to the body file that is currently open.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Starts a new body file for each output object.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Starts a new body file for each page of output.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Starts a new body file each time that you start a new procedure.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Instructs ODS not to insert contents data into the RTF file.

[Syntax: OPERATOR= 'text-string'] 
          
Inserts the text you specify into the metadata of the RTF file.

[Syntax: PACKAGE <package-name>] 
          
Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package. 
          
package-name 
specifies the name of a package that was created with the ODS PACKAGE statement. 
If no name is specified, then the output is added to the unnamed package that was 
opened last.

Syntax: PATH= 'aggregate-file-storage-specification' | fileref | libref.catalog (URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE) 
   
Specifies the location of an aggregate storage location or a SAS catalog for all markup files. 
If the GPATH= option is not specified, all graphics output files are written to the 
"aggregate-file-storage-specification" or libref.

  'aggregate-file-storage-location' -- specifies an aggregate storage location such as directory, folder, or partitioned data set.
  Requirement: You must enclose aggregate-file-storage-location in quotation marks. 

  fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an aggregate storage location. 
  Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref.

    Interaction: If you use a fileref in the PATH= option, then ODS does not use information from 
    PATH= when it constructs links. 

  libref.catalog -- specifies a SAS catalog to write to.

  URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE -- specifies a URL for the file-specification. 

    Uniform-Resource-Locator 
    is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references that it creates to the file.

    NONE 
    specifies that no information from the PATH= option appears in the links or references.

Syntax: RECORD_SEPARATOR= 'alternative-separator' | NONE 
    
Specifies an alternative character or string that separates lines in the output files.

Different operating environments use different separator characters. If you do not specify a record 
separator, then the files are formatted for the environment where you run the SAS job. However, 
if you are generating files for viewing in a different operating environment that uses a different 
separator character, then you can specify a record separator that is appropriate for the target environment.

alternative-separator -- represents one or more characters in hexadecimal or ASCII format. For example, 
the following option specifies a record separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character 
for use with an ASCII file system: 

  RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D0A'x
  
Operating Environment Information:   In a mainframe environment, the option that specifies a record 
separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character for use with an ASCII file system is: 

  RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D25'x
  Requirement: You must enclose alternative-separator in quotation marks. 

NONE -- produces the markup language that is appropriate for the environment where you run the SAS job.

Writes to the RTF file the time and the date that you started your SAS session. 

Restriction: You can specify SASDATE only when you open a new file. If you specify the option 
at any other time, ODS writes a warning message to the SAS log.
Controls page breaks.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies not to insert page breaks, even before graphics procedures.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that no new pages be inserted at the beginning of each procedure, or within certain  procedures, even if new pages are requested by the procedure code. A new page will begin only  when a page is filled or when you specify STARTPAGE=NOW.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Forces the immediate insertion of a new page.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Inserts a new page at the beginning of each procedure, and within certain procedures, as requested  by the procedure code.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: STYLE= style-definition] 
          
Specifies the style definition for ODS to use to write the RTF files.

[Syntax: TEXT= 'text-string'] 
          
Inserts text into your RTF output. 
          
Restriction: You cannot use both the NEWFILE= and TEXT= options in the same ODS RTF statement. 
You must use a separate ODS RTF statement for each of these options. 

Requirement: You must enclose a text-string in quotation marks.

[Syntax: TITLE= 'title-text'] 
          
Inserts the text string that you specify as the title into the metadata of a file.

title-text 
is the text in the metadata of a file that indicates the title.

Requirement: You must enclose a title-text in quotation marks.
Instructs ODS to insert contents data into the RTF file.

Syntax: TRANTAB= 'translation-table' 
          
Specifies the translation table to use when transcoding a file for output.

Syntax: EXCLUDE exclusion(s)| ALL | NONE 
          
Excludes output objects from the RTF destination.
Closes the RTF destination and any files that are associated with it.
See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.
See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.

Syntax: SELECT selection(s) | ALL | NONE 
          
Selects output objects for the RTF destination.
Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

[Syntax: ANCHOR='anchor-name'] 
          
Specifies the base name for the RTF anchor tag that identifies each output object 
in the current file.

[Syntax: AUTHOR='author-text'] 
          
Inserts the text string that you specify as the author into the metadata of a file.

Specifies the text to use as the first part of all references that ODS creates in the output files.

Syntax: BASE= 'base-text'

base-text 
is the text that ODS uses as the first part of all references that ODS creates in the file.

Consider this specification: 

BASE='http://www.your-company.com/local-url/'
In this case, ODS creates references that begin with the string http://www.your-company.com/local-url/. 
The appropriate anchor-name completes the link.

Specifies that SAS titles and footnotes are placed into the body of the RTF document 
instead of into the headers and footers section of the RTF document.

Restriction: The BODYTITLE option can be specified only when you create a new RTF file.

Specifies that SAS titles and footnotes be placed into the body of the RTF document 
instead of into the headers and footers section of the RTF document. These titles 
and footnotes are put into cells, which allows titles and footnotes to be centered, 
left-justified, or right-justified.

Restriction: You can specify the BODYTITLE_AUX option only when you are creating a new 
RTF file.

[Syntax: COLUMNS=n | MAX] 
          
Specifies the number of columns to place across each page of output. 
            
Default: the number of one-inch columns that fit on the page.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Is the number of one-inch columns that you want on the page.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the maximum number of one-inch-wide columns for the paper size and margin setting.  This value is dependent upon the paper size and page orientation.
